information:
China's Consumer Price Index (CPI) has registered three consecutive months of year-on-year deflation: -0.7% in February, -0.1% in March, and -0.1% in April 2025. The Producer Price Index (PPI), a measure of factory-gate prices, has also shown sustained deflationary pressure, declining for 31 consecutive months. In April, the PPI fell by 2.7% year-on-year, the largest decline in six months. Core CPI, which excludes food and energy, has remained positive but low, at around +0.5% year-on-year.

China's manufacturing activity contracted for the second consecutive month in May, with the manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) standing at 49.5, below the 50-point mark that separates growth from contraction. The non-manufacturing PMI also showed a slight decline to 50.3 in May from 50.4 in the previous month. In the property sector, new-home sales from the 100 largest developers fell by 8.6% year-on-year in May, following an 8.7% drop in April.

Specific components influencing China's inflation data include energy and food prices. Brent crude oil averaged $84 in May 2025, a 4% increase from a year earlier. However, the year-on-year change in domestic energy prices remained negative. Pork prices, a key component of the food basket, also remained lower than a year ago due to high inventories. On the policy front, the People's Bank of China implemented a 10 basis point reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut in mid-May.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 10–16 days (NBS May CPI typically releases around June 12; FRED usually updates a couple of days after)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes — another very small negative y/y print (around -0.1%), extending deflation to a fourth month
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Holiday-driven services firmness (travel, accommodation, airfares) plus slightly less negative energy and stabilization in pork push headline CPI to 0.0% or +0.1% y/y; FRED rounds to 0.0 or +0.1, yielding No
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Food and domestic energy stay negative y/y and demand remains soft; May m/m is flat-to-negative (seasonally common with cheaper vegetables), leaving headline at about -0.1% y/y and FRED rounds negative
forecast.rationale: Baseline conditions point to another marginally negative headline. We already have three consecutive negative y/y prints (Feb -0.7%, Mar -0.1%, Apr -0.1). PPI deflation deepened to -2.7% y/y in April, PMIs show manufacturing contraction in May (49.5), property remains weak, and pork prices are still below last year — all consistent with subdued consumer price pressure. The research assistant also notes domestic energy prices remain negative y/y despite Brent being ~4% higher y/y, so energy likely still drags. Core CPI is modestly positive (~+0.5% y/y), signaling underlying inflation isn’t collapsing, but it has not been strong enough to offset food/energy drags in recent months. Seasonal factors are mixed: May often sees services strength around the Labor Day holiday, but food (notably vegetables) can be softer m/m. Given April was -0.1% and the structure of drivers hasn’t materially changed, the status quo favors another small negative print. Why not higher: holiday-related services firmness, a slightly less negative energy contribution, and the fact core is positive could lift headline to 0.0%/+0.1%. Rounding on FRED is a real risk near zero (e.g., -0.04% could display 0.0%). Why not lower: policy easing (RRR cut) and higher global oil versus a year ago provide some offset; sustained core positivity suggests outright deeper deflation is unlikely. What would move me upward (toward Yes): continued weakness in high-frequency food prices (pork/veg) through late May, reports of negative month-on-month headline, or analyst consensus tilting to negative. What would move me downward (toward No): indications of strong services inflation from holiday travel, a clear rebound in pork, or previews/consensus pointing to 0.0% or +0.1% with emphasis on rounding risk.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will China experience a 4th month in a row of deflation in its May CPI report?

Question background:
SCMP: [China’s consumer prices fall in April, fuelling fears of deflation](https://www.scmp.com/economy/economic-indicators/article/3309834/chinas-consumer-prices-fall-april-fuelling-fears-deflation)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the "Percent Change from Year Ago, Not Seasonally Adjusted" data presented at [FRED Consumer Price Indices (CPIs, HICPs), COICOP 1999: Consumer Price Index: Total for China (CHNCPIALLMINMEI)](https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/CHNCPIALLMINMEI#) is negative for May 2025.




Your research assistant's report says:
China's Consumer Price Index (CPI) has registered three consecutive months of year-on-year deflation: -0.7% in February, -0.1% in March, and -0.1% in April 2025. The Producer Price Index (PPI), a measure of factory-gate prices, has also shown sustained deflationary pressure, declining for 31 consecutive months. In April, the PPI fell by 2.7% year-on-year, the largest decline in six months. Core CPI, which excludes food and energy, has remained positive but low, at around +0.5% year-on-year.

China's manufacturing activity contracted for the second consecutive month in May, with the manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) standing at 49.5, below the 50-point mark that separates growth from contraction. The non-manufacturing PMI also showed a slight decline to 50.3 in May from 50.4 in the previous month. In the property sector, new-home sales from the 100 largest developers fell by 8.6% year-on-year in May, following an 8.7% drop in April.

Specific components influencing China's inflation data include energy and food prices. Brent crude oil averaged $84 in May 2025, a 4% increase from a year earlier. However, the year-on-year change in domestic energy prices remained negative. Pork prices, a key component of the food basket, also remained lower than a year ago due to high inventories. On the policy front, the People's Bank of China implemented a 10 basis point reserve requirement ratio (RRR) cut in mid-May.

Today is 2025-06-02.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
